It is another year before anyone can actually enforce the provisions of this law. What real difference will a handful of weeks make? Well, in terms of making the bill work and getting a good outcome, I think a considerable difference. Whilst I have my disagreements with colleagues in the Senate, they're the house of review, and they do their job and do it well.
A government member interjecting—

Mr PITT: On occasion! I hear the interjection from the minister at the dispatch box. Even the eSafety Commissioner has expressed concern for those who may bypass the age media restrictions, who potentially use social media in secrecy. I think we all know those kids already whose parents have said, 'No, you can't have a social media account,' so they set one up and use it somewhere else. They do that right now. I think they'll rapidly find a way around this legislation. Whilst that's disappointing, it's reality.

Is there a better way? Let's give the Senate the opportunity to find out. Take the submissions, take the evidence, talk to the experts and make it better. The government has bipartisan support. What difference will it make? A delay will not mean that it will not pass, but a delay could well mean that it functions far better than it currently looks like it might. Intent is wonderful; reality is different. I come back to all of those sporting groups, community groups, small groups and schools right across our nation who utilise social media as their means of communications, particularly with our youth. What do they do? How do they deal with it? How much work is being created? Will it actually work?

I continue to have concerns with the bill. I continue to have concerns about those two primary functions: will it work and why can't we do a proper inquiry? We have seen any number of inquiries. We have seen any number of pieces of legislation kicked off into the long grass, into a Senate committee. That has happened hundreds of times, but I cannot for a moment understand the urgency to pass this bill this week when it could so easily be different.

I say to my community, to the people who send me to this place, I'm trying to put forward your views and your concerns. I read a number of those out at the commencement of this speech. I'll continue to talk to them to hear what their views are and whether they think it will function. I've got to say I've got any number who tell me it simply won't. They think, literally, it's a joke and that you have to be kidding. I'll come back to where I started. I have a long-held view that we must do something, I just don't know if this is the answer.

Dr HAINES (Indi) (20:11): As parents, one of our most constant concerns is the wellbeing of our children. From their first moments through schooling and into adulthood, we give our hearts and minds into caring for them, loving them and helping them develop to their full potential. There are so many experiences we want them to have, and, in parallel, we seek to protect our kids from things that we are worried about.

I'm sure most parents would agree with me that being a parent is a lifetime gig. We shelter our kids as best we can and then we learn to gradually let go as they make their own way in life. Every parent knows there are many challenges in raising a family and obstacles along the way that are constantly changing. And we second-guess ourselves. We ask ourselves: are we getting it right?

Every generation has faced challenges. There's no doubt about that. But today we're navigating incredible challenges posed by social media and the online world. We face dangers as well as opportunities in that world. But these dangers and opportunities are ones that no generation before us has faced, and what's abundantly clear is that the online world is a world where the rules and mores of the cultures we've relied on for generations to guide us no longer apply. As parents, we simply don't have the tools to keep our kids safe in this space. Yes, social media has been a part of our lives now for many years, but it's more omnipresent than ever in our lives. It's more addictive, more divisive and more harmful. The optimism of the noughties has made way for the harsh realities of the 2020s.

I speak with parents, who often tell me stories of children exposed to pornography through social media, of primary school aged children relentlessly bullied and tormented online, of teenagers struggling with eating disorders being bombarded with dieting advice and of spiralling declines in mental health and increases in suicide. We're all now so familiar with these stories. One mother told me that her young family had travelled around Australia camping and engaging in nature. She and her husband worked hard to instil the love of the natural world in their kids, to know and love the real rather than the virtual. Years later, she's now in utter disbelief that her teenager is addicted to social media.

Another parent wrote to me saying she was 'crying out' for my support for this ban on social media. I've heard from parents imploring me to support this bill to ban social media full stop because they're living with the consequence of these harms to their children and scared for the future of our broader society. And I don't blame them. But I've also heard from parents saying the absolute opposite. I've heard from people worried that the government is interfering where it shouldn't and from others begging me for government intervention. There truly are mixed feelings about this.

The reality is that right now parents and teachers are shouldering all the burden. While a child's online life might be out of sight, it's certainly not out of mind. It's reasonable to say that we feel helpless because we're up against the full weight of social media and big corporate tech. But can we put the genie back in the bottle? Should we just accept this as the new world and keep trying to guide our kids and ourselves? Should we try to educate more? Should we cave to the cult of inevitability, that this is way out of control and anything we try to do to curb and control social media will not work?

We've heard about the difficulties of implementation. We've heard the question: will it work? The member for Hinkler has just expressed those reservations. I get it. I ask those questions, too. Alongside that, for young people today, this online world is the only one they've known. They grow up seeing every adult around them with a mobile phone. Young people communicate with their friends and find entertainment across the internet. They organise meet-ups and sports trainings. Kids with niche interests find their tribes. Let's be clear: there are true perceived benefits of social media.

Yesterday, Project Rockit gave evidence to the last-minute Senate inquiry into the bill that gave voice to the under-16s who were not in the room to speak for social media, for whom social media has helped them figure out and become comfortable with their sense of self, for whom social media has given them a voice when they might not otherwise like they do or to find like-minded people they might not otherwise meet. This is especially true for young people living in regional areas, for a person of colour or for queer kids. I acknowledge this, and I have heard and considered the words of mental health experts who speak to this. The benefits feel like they are not outweighing the harms. If they did, we would see social media companies creating safe online spaces, but that's not what we're seeing. Instead, we're seeing platforms where children experience addiction, distraction, alienation and polarisation.

Interestingly—and maybe others have read this—earlier this year, the Guardian reported on parents working at large tech companies saying that they did not trust that their industry would prioritise child safety without public regulatory pressure. That's pretty telling—if you want to know who a good surgeon is, ask the theatre nurse. This is the world that children face. We know parents are doing their best, but they cannot protect their kids or change social media platforms on their own. So, as legislators and as a parliament, we have to back our parents—the parents of Australia. That brings us to the bill today.

The bill before us seeks to significantly limit children's access to social media. But how should we tackle this problem? There's no clear consensus on the right approach and whether a blanket ban is the right or best response for Australia. As an Independent member of the parliament, I am forced to review every single bill that comes before me on its merits, but, to be honest, this one is incredibly difficult to assess. The evidence base is complex to interpret, and, in this case, the time to do so is extremely rushed. I acknowledge I knew this bill was coming, even though I only had it in my hands for a matter of days. Knowing it was coming, I sought to understand the views of my community, both for and against this vexing issue. I've heard and listened to the perspectives of people across my electorate. I have listened to my parliamentary colleagues. I've been briefed by the minister in the department. I've attended many briefings from other groups here in the parliament. Importantly, I've spoken with young people who will be affected by this bill, and their voices really matter in this debate.

The Online Safety Amendment (Social Media Minimum Age) Bill 2024 would require social media platforms to take reasonable steps to prevent children under the age of 16 from accessing their platforms. The bill will do this by defining an age-restricted user, meaning an Australian child under the age of 16. The bill will also introduce a new definition for an 'age-restricted social media platform' as one whose sole or significant purpose is to enable users to post material online and interact socially.

The bill then introduces an obligation on providers of an age-restricted social media platform to take reasonable steps to prevent age-restricted users from having an account with the platform. The proposed model will include platforms such as Facebook, Instagram, TikTok and Snapchat. The government says it intends to prescribe rules that exclude messaging apps, such as WhatsApp, online gaming platforms and services with the primary purpose of supporting the health and education of end users. Civil penalty provisions will enable fines of up to $50 million to apply to age-restricted platforms that fail to prevent children under 16 accessing their platforms.

That's what's in the bill, but there are many questions we still don't have answers to. For example, it's unclear how platforms will manage existing users under 16. We don't know how the requirement to take reasonable steps will be assessed or defined. My office has heard from many constituents concerned about how age verification will occur. Will all users be required to upload identity documents? Will digital ID services be used or required? I raised these concerns with the minister's office and I understand the government intends to make amendments in the other place that will clarify that digital ID services will not be a mandatory part of online verification or assurance, However, the government's age-assurance trial, meant to investigate best-practice age-assurance technology hasn't even begun yet. Departmental officials tell me that this trial will inform the government's rules for social media platforms. But we don't know what this will look like.

There's also no certainty about how these bans will operate in practice, and there's a consensus that they will not be fully effective. No matter how tightly designed, some young people will circumvent restrictions to access social media. Some will do this with parental approval and some without. Some will use VPNs. One constituent wrote to me, concerned that a rushed social media ban will result in underground sites filling the void. There will be zero transparency and zero control for parents or authorities. This raises important questions: If we know there will be gaps, will teens who bypass these restrictions be vulnerable to even greater harm? Will the benefits outweigh any negative consequences? That is why the government must commit to robust ongoing scrutiny of this bill's implementation. We must be alive to the impacts of this bill on children and on the wider population, both positive and negative, and be prepared to adapt as circumstances change and more evidence becomes available. We need to be a flexible respondent to this.

It also raises the question of whether this policy, this blanket ban, is the best way to reduce the harms young people experience on social media. For example, if addictive algorithms are the main problem, could they be targeted or regulated in another way? If exposure to violent content is the problem, how could we ensure young people see less of this while remaining on platforms and enjoying the benefits that social media can provide if properly designed?

These are important questions that have not been adequately addressed in the public sphere. Both the government and the opposition are quick to call for a total ban because it's easy to communicate. It's decisive. It seems to be popular. But this doesn't mean it's the best or only solution to the problem. That's why we must consider this proposal alongside other key reforms, many of which were put forward by the Joint Select Committee on Social Media and Australian Society. For example, I welcome the government's intention to legislate a statutory duty of care for online platforms to reduce harms for all Australians, a key recommendation of the inquiry. I agree with the minister that we must move away from simply responding to harms and embrace systems based prevention that requires the big tech companies to design platforms that are safer for not only children but all of us. It's why we must consider reforms that give users, young and old, more control over the sharing and use of their online data, and it's why we must prioritise reforms to the Privacy Act, which is something I've said time and time again. The social media ban for children cannot exist in a vacuum.

Unfortunately, the major parties seem disinclined to properly scrutinise this bill, and it appears likely to pass the House imminently. The Senate inquiry into this bill had just a single day for submissions and a single hearing yesterday of only a few hours. This is to our detriment. When bills are properly scrutinised they're improved, and for such significant legislation and such profound trade-offs there must be adequate scrutiny. It's just another example of where this government will seek to ram things through the parliament when there's a political imperative.

This bill is a bold step, and we don't have a full picture of what the unintended consequences may be, whether good or bad. We must be vigilant as the social media ban is implemented and be prepared to change course if necessary. Where I've landed is that there is a cause for intervention. We've put in a limit on cigarettes and drinking, but we continue to minimise harm, to educate and to inform. We know it hasn't fixed it completely, in those cases, but it has reduced harm. We can protect children and continue to educate.

I hope this bill will prompt more conversations at dinner tables and school gates across Australia about online spaces, finding our way in worlds physical and digital and how we can make social media safer for all of us. Here, in this place, we must continue to pursue reforms that require the social media companies to design better and safer platforms. If we get that right, we will all benefit.

This has been one of the most difficult bills to make a decision on. Quite frankly, standing here right now, I could go either way because there are strong arguments to be made for banning social media for under 16s, through legislation, and there are strong arguments to be made for not doing that and for taking another course. I go back to my fundamental public health training, where I have seen harm minimisation through the legislative work of a government. In this case, my decision is that I will support this bill reluctantly because we must start to act as a parliament to protect our children in the online spaces. I wish it had more scrutiny, I truly do, but that's where I land.

Ms CHANEY (Curtin) (20:26): This Online Safety Amendment (Social Media Minimum Age) Bill 2024 requires social media platforms to take reasonable steps to exclude people under 16 from creating accounts. While I have concerns about the process, the risk to privacy, the unintended consequences and the bluntness of this tool, I recognise that there is significant community concern about kids and social media. I've consulted widely with my electorate, and the majority of people who engaged wanted a social media ban for children, so I will be supporting this bill.

This bill introduces a new definition of an age-restricted social media platform whose sole or significant purpose is to enable users to post material online and interact socially with other users. The bill will attempt to force owners of newly defined age-restricted social media platforms to take reasonable steps to prevent people under 16 from having a user account, so kids under 16 can't establish an account on any of these platforms but can still view the platforms while they are logged out. The bill includes an exclusion framework that exempts messaging apps such as WhatsApp, online gaming platforms and services with the primary purpose of supporting the health and education of end users. The onus will be on the platform to restrict under 16s. Platforms could face fines of nearly $50 million, if they don't take reasonable steps.

I have some serious concerns about a number of aspects of the bill. Firstly, I have concerns about the process the bill is gone through, or lack thereof. In what's becoming a bad habit for this government, we're seeing this pretty significant change being rushed through. The government tells us that they've consulted widely in drafting this bill, but, here we are again, rushing through legislation that has barely been scrutinised.

We, on the crossbench, first saw this legislation last week. There was a three-hour committee inquiry yesterday. Stakeholders were given three days to provide submissions and, even so, 15,000 people managed to get submissions in. The committee report just dropped, a day after the only hearing. Quite frankly, that's ridiculous. When asked, 'Why the rush?' the government effectively said that they'd agreed with the opposition to do this before Christmas. We have no idea how or when the government and the opposition stitched up this deal or why, to be honest. The process is awful. This legislation is a world first. There's no well-trodden path here, but we are rushing it through.

The Joint Select Committee on Social Media and Australian Society sat for six months to produce a report this month on how social media is used in Australia. One of the specific terms of reference was for the committee to inquire into the use of age-verification to protect Australian children from social media. In the report, there were contrasting views on whether making it safer for children means preventing them from accessing social media until they reach a certain age. The committee did not recommend a ban on access; they instead recommended a single and overarching statutory duty of care on digital platforms for the wellbeing of their Australian users. Despite this recommendation, the government is proceeding with a ban, and proceeding now—today—despite there being 12 months before the legislation comes into effect, despite there being limited public scrutiny and despite there being limited clarity on how the ban will be enforced. This is my biggest concern. This is no way to make laws.

When it comes to the ban itself, one of the big risks—it's one of the reasons we need a proper inquiry—is that we might throw the baby out with the bathwater. Social media is arguably now a crucial form of modern communication and socialisation. We can't turn the clock back to the wholesome childhood I had in the 1980s, where I was climbing trees, riding my bike with friends and watching The Goodies. The world has changed. In October, more than 140 experts wrote an open letter to the Prime Minister, Anthony Albanese, in which they said 'a "ban" is too blunt an instrument to address risks effectively'. The Australian Human Rights Commission has now added its voice to the opposition to the ban. I hear mixed reports about the positive mental health impact of social media. I've heard it said that, for young people in crisis, social media can often be both the cause of trauma and also the channel they use to seek help.

There's no doubt young people can connect with communities beyond their immediate geographic world using social media, and this can help make them feel less alone. It's very challenging to balance this benefit against the harm we hear so much about: the bullying, the comparisons against an ideal, the harmful content, the porn, the eating disorder material, the extremist views and the predators. But we must acknowledge that it's not all bad and that young people will have fewer connection opportunities than they have now without access to social media.

Another big concern is enforcement. It's not clear how this will be enforced, and this raises a number of risks. The first is that it's just not enforced and it doesn't work. Second is that, at best, it's a tool for parents to use—saying it's against the law—but kids can get around it. If this happens, it has some value for parents, but we have to be realistic about how much of a difference it will actually make. But if it is enforced through some sort of age verification process, these platforms will have all our data. They already have a lot of data, but adding to that is problematic. There's no point in going into the detail of the privacy issues here. Apparently, we need to wait and see what the age verification trial uncovers, so what will constitute reasonable steps to prevent young people creating an account remains to be seen. This is a pretty big gap in the legislation, and there's a good argument to postpone the legislation until we know what, if anything, actually works.

Another significant concern is that a ban for under-16s lets the platforms off the hook when it comes to creating safe spaces. The committee report I mentioned refers to widespread agreement that a ban alone is not sufficient to curb harms on social media. A ban for under-16s may actually give the platforms licence to avoid other regulation. The government has said that, while legislating an age limit might not be the perfect solution and should certainly not be the only solution, it would provide important breathing space for the implementation of long-term, sustainable digital reforms. So it's important that this isn't the end of the story when it comes to regulating social media platforms. It's the wild west out there. We could definitely be doing this in a more nuanced way if we took the time to examine it more closely, and many of my crossbench colleagues are proposing amendments to broaden the scope or focus of regulation, and I'll be backing those amendments.

The EU is requiring social media platforms to do a risk assessment on any new features they add to an app. For example, TikTok added a feature in France and Spain which would encourage addictive behaviour. They failed to submit a risk assessment, so the European Commission banned the feature. Other options that I think should be considered in parallel with this blunt tool are regulating algorithms, legislating a duty of care and risk assessments, or making social media companies provide greater transparency and data so we can actually understand how algorithms work and decide if they're in the public interest. But, and it's a pretty big 'but', there is a strong desire from communities to see immediate protection for children.

I'm a parent of teenagers and I know that I rarely have a conversation with other parents of teenagers that doesn't involve us talking about the impacts of screens and social media on our kids. We are conducting a huge experiment on a whole generation, and it's raising serious concerns. We don't know how much is too much, whether we're turning our kids into zombies or depriving them of normal social interaction. As parents, we see growing mental health issues in teens, and you can't help thinking it's connected with the biggest change in the last generation—the ubiquity of smartphones and technology in every aspect of life. Even if it is a blunt tool, this ban should protect children and young people from cyberbullying, harmful content and online predators as well as go some way to safeguarding their psychological and emotional wellbeing. Hopefully it will give kids time to be kids offline. It will also protect their data from being harvested. No matter how it is enforced and whether it is well enforced, it at least gives parents the ability to hold the line and tell their kids, 'You can't have social media, because it's against the law.'

On balance it seems that people in Curtin, or at least those who have engaged on the issue, largely support a ban. I conducted an online survey in Curtin some months ago with nearly 600 respondents, promoted through social media and also in the local Post newspaper. This is obviously not the whole community, but these are the ones who have expressed an interest and a view. The key themes that came out of this survey were that protection of children is paramount, that there was broad support for a minimum age for social media use, that there was broad support for legislation that covers emerging harms and technologies, and that people felt that platforms should have a statutory duty of care. Specifically on the minimum age for social media use, 86 per cent of respondents wanted a minimum age for social media. Of those, 45 per cent wanted the age to be 16 years. This was by far the most popular minimum age in the survey. But only 57 per cent said that they were willing to share their personal information.

I also asked my youth advisory group, a group of year 11s from across Curtin, about it. Even with that group there was a surprising level of support for a ban for under-16s. One youth advisory group member, Christian, pointed out that 16 is pretty old—the same as the age for sexual consent—and that maybe a younger age would be better or that it should be up to parents to regulate. All the young people I've spoken to thought that a duty of care and greater obligations on platforms to create safe spaces were a better option than a total ban. But Alice pointed out that social media and doomscrolling are a recent thing and that people long before us have survived without them. She pointed out that social media changes our whole way of living and communicating with each other and it's sending us in the wrong direction.

When I asked how a ban would have affected them when they were under 16, none of them were devastated at the idea. Oban said that, if none of his friends were using these platforms, it would have been fine. Isabella said she wouldn't have felt left out if her friends were also not allowed social media. Miles said he and his friends would have migrated to more direct communications platforms instead. Even my year 11 work experience student, Alasdair Watson, while arguing vigorously against the ban, admitted that he would probably have been better off without social media before he was 16. In the new year, I'll be working with my youth advisory group using an innovative technology platform to do broader community research into how young people think social media platforms should be regulated. I had planned to do that before this bill came up this week, and I will continue with that next February, even in light of this legislation, because there is so much more to do.

In conclusion, we should continue to examine and evolve our regulatory approach to this rapidly changing but ubiquitous part of modern life. But I reluctantly concede that this ban for under-16s may be a useful first blunt tool. So, despite my concern about the ridiculously rushed process, the risk to privacy if it's enforced or pointlessness if it's not enforced and the need to do a lot more to create safe online spaces, I will be supporting this bill.

Ms SPENDER (Wentworth) (20:39): I rise to speak on the Online Safety Amendment (Social Media Minimum Age) Bill 2024. This bill seeks to address the significant challenges that social media has created for young people in Australia by setting a minimum age of 16 for platforms like TikTok, Snapchat and Instagram. The harms caused by social media are a big issue for my community, where I've spoken to countless parents, including many of my friends, who are deeply concerned about the impact that these platforms are having on their kids. We're even seeing some innovation coming out of Wentworth because of these concerns, including the 36 Months program as well as Wait Mate.

Earlier this year my office conducted a survey on online safety and the results were striking. Around nine in 10 respondents expressed concern about the impact of social media on young people, highlighting issues like online bullying, screen addiction and exposure to harmful content. This bill seeks to respond to these concerns by requiring platforms to prevent under-16s from holding social media accounts and introducing strong penalties for platforms that fail to comply. From eastern Sydney to every corner of Australia, parents are grappling with how to manage the impacts of children's and young people's social media use. Research by the eSafety Commissioner shows that 95 per cent of caregivers report online safety as being one of their toughest parenting challenges, and these concerns were echoed in my own community survey.

In Wentworth, 83 per cent of respondents identified online bullying as their top worry, citing the emotional harm caused by negative interactions online, and these fears are not unfounded: 44 per cent of Australian young reported negative online experience in the six months to September 2020 and 15 per cent reported receiving threats or abuse online. In addition to bullying, 81 per cent of people in my community were concerned about social media addiction, where endless scrolling and notifications disrupt sleep, relationships and academic performance. Again, their fears are well founded. Professor Wayne Warburton's research demonstrates that screen addiction is linked to changes in children's brains, affecting decision-making, empathy and impulse control.

A further 78 per cent of people told me they were worried about exposure to pornography and its impact on perceptions of relationships and consent. Again, this was an issue raised with me by the faith leaders of Wentworth, whom I have brought together in a group. They talked about this being one of the big issues that is raised in their faith communities. One parent shared their story: 'When my kids got given iPads at their tech public school, this is when a lot of problems started. My son was eight years old when he was exposed to porn after a kid in the school group chat posted a word and he looked it up at his grandparents, who didn't have the right internet controls. Needless to say, this had a devastating effect on our family.'

There were many other concerns shared with me. Seventy-five per cent were worried about content contributing to body image issues and eating disorders, three-quarters flagged concerns about harmful content directed at women, and 73 per cent raised issues around violent and extreme content. My community experienced the consequences of the latter firsthand following the tragedy at Bondi Junction earlier this year. In the aftermath of the stabbings, shocking videos of the attack circulated widely online and parents I spoke to were horrified to find that much of this footage had been seen by their children on social media. It's clear that social media is not safe for young people and that the government does need to act.

Before turning to the substance, I want to put on record my concerns with the process surrounding this bill, which has been shambolic. It was introduced last Thursday, and stakeholders were given 24 hours to submit to a Senate inquiry. This inquiry was due to report back in a few days, making it impossible for the committee to receive and consider sufficient evidence on this bill. As Digital Rights Watch said:
Never before have we witnessed such a shocking display of misusing the committee inquiry process as a sham consultation for the purposes of "box-ticking" community engagement.

This is not how you make good laws. Instead of a proper inquiry, the government intends to pass the bill in just a couple of days. It's completely inadequate to assess the consequences of such a wide-ranging piece of legislation that in many ways is actually world leading. Is there sufficient evidence that banning social media for under-16s will work? Have privacy considerations been properly taken into account? Are there unintended consequences, like limiting young people's access to peer support networks, especially in areas like mental health? Maybe. Maybe not. We certainly will not know by the time this bill has been rammed through the House, and that is hugely concerning.

Unfortunately, we have seen this rushed approach before. Last week, changes to electoral laws that entrench the incumbency advantage of the major parties were rammed through this House without an inquiry, despite their far-reaching consequences. And, while this has been rushed through for political expediency, bills which could have been brought to the parliament—bills for which we have a lot of community support and which have had, frankly, more investigation—have not been on the table, such as a ban on gambling advertising. Banning gambling ads is too complex, apparently, yet we're also meant to believe that an unprecedented overhaul of how young people access social media is straightforward and to pass it in less than a week. The inconsistency is striking.

Turning to the substance of the bill, there is no doubt that an age limit is a blunt instrument but, if well designed, could be part of a solution to reducing social media harm. It reflects the concerns in my community, where 64 per cent of respondents said they supported a social media ban for under-16s. Parents in Wentworth don't think social media platforms are safe for young people, and they want action. They want their kids to grow up playing outside with their friends, to learn and grow from real experiences, rather than sharing everything through the medium of a screen.

I acknowledge that age limit is not a silver bullet, but I do think that the most important thing it provides is parents with a powerful reason to say no. It sets a new standard in our community, backing in mums and dads who are worried about their kids' mental health, wellbeing and self-confidence. As a mother of a 12-year-old whose friends have just started to get social media accounts, it will be helpful. I don't want my children to miss out—and so many parents are the same—but, at the same time, I don't want my children to be on these platforms. I know that that is a feeling that many parents share. The age limit has had the support of numerous experts, such as the 120 mental health clinicians and experts, led by Professor Jonathan Haidt, who joined together to call for a ban earlier this year.

I think one point that has been raised with me consistently and that I'll come back to again is that this ban may not actually be effective. But, still, I think the concern for most parents is: 'It gives me a reason to say no.' I also think the ban could provide a useful and powerful push to social media companies to start to take greater action to self-regulate, because they have not yet taken the action that they could take, and I think this ban should hopefully send them a message that unfettered development, with lack of regard for the impact on individuals, will have consequences.

There are also some important nuances built into the legislation. Messaging platforms, crucial for making personal connections, are exempt from the new age limit, as are online gaming services, which already have age classifications. Services that primarily support the health or education of end users will also be excluded, and an independent review is planned after two years to assess the bill's effectiveness.

While parts of this legislation are positive, we need broader action to address online harm and stronger incentives for social media companies to make their platforms safe. The bill acknowledges that social media is not safe for young people, but it does nothing to address the ongoing dangers posed to older teenagers and adults or those young people who inevitably will get on these platforms even with a social media ban in place. It does not address the wide range of factors contributing to harm, such as design features, infinite scrolls, algorithms and content amplification systems. It is founded on the hope that age-assurance technologies will prove to be accurate and appropriate, despite the government's own age-assurance trial having not even finished yet.

As numerous experts have pointed out, to create a genuinely safe and empowering online environment for all Australians, we need a systems approach. One critical component of this is an overarching duty of care for social media platforms. This would hold them accountable for the harm that they cause and compel them to take preventive action. Alongside this duty of care, we also need much more transparency around the algorithms used to serve content to users. This transparency should be going hand in hand with end-user control obligations, such as giving people the ability to opt out of targeted advertising and reset their personal algorithms.

These measures are included in the private member's bill tabled yesterday by the member of Goldstein, and I want to commend her for all the work that she has done in this space. I wish that the government had not rushed through this legislation without using this as an opportunity for these wider reforms at the same time, as well as education, which was identified by the young people in Wentworth I spoke to as being critical for online safety.

I want to note four concerns with the bill, all of which should have been addressed as part of a proper committee inquiry. The first relates to the unintended consequences of a blanket ban. As mental health organisations like ReachOut, Beyond Blue and the Black Dog Institute highlighted in their recent joint letter, there can be beneficial impacts of social media for young people. Banning it altogether could prevent them from accessing important peer support networks, particularly in relation to health issues and especially for communities that could be otherwise isolated in their geographical community. I urge the government to work with these organisations to ensure access to crucial services is not affected. The unintended consequences of a blanket ban could also mean that social media companies do not innovate in ways that are more responsible in terms of harm for young people. There is potentially a world where social media is available for young people but does not have the addictive and other qualities that make it so harmful, but a blanket ban means that we don't have those potential innovation opportunities unless some change is made to this legislation.

My second concern relates to privacy. Serious questions have been raised about how platforms will implement age-assurance requirements, what data will be collected and how it will be stored or used. This could have significant implications not just for children but also for the adults who use the platforms. As the Tech Council noted in their submission to the Senate enquiry:
The Bill places a heavy onus on technology providers to verify age, which would need to be done for every user of a platform.

The government has stated that the bill includes strict privacy controls and that any age-assurance data will be swiftly deleted by the platform. I hope this is correct, but we are taking it on trust.

My third concern relates to the new definition of 'social media' and the use of legislative instruments. As the Digital Research Centre, Tech Council and others have noticed, this bill introduces a novel definition of 'social media', potentially adding confusion in an already-complex policy space. A huge amount of discretion is provided to the minister to rule particular companies in or out of scope of the ban, causing confusion and uncertainty among technology companies. A few days ago we heard that YouTube would be excluded from the ban, but what about Reddit, Strava or other platforms that emerge over time or perhaps evolve over time as well? Are these companies also going to be subject to the $50 million in fines that are applicable under this legislation, and will this inhibit innovation in the Australian tech sector, which is so important to us?

Finally, the broader concern is whether this is actually going to work. There are challenges because of potential uses of VPNs and the evolution of platforms perhaps outside the ban. I can see a world where YouTube basically evolves to be TikTok but without people being able to post. But will we end up with the same addictive qualities in that innovation of YouTube that, frankly, means that TikTok is excluded but YouTube still creates those same social harms. When I spoke to my youth action committee in Wentworth and groups of year 5 and year 6 students about this potential ban as well as to groups of years 10 and 11 about this ban, they all said it's probably or possibly, on balance, a good idea—that was the overarching feeling—but a real concern is that it just isn't possible and it's just not practically going to work. What we should be doing is really educating our young people and giving them the skills to manage social media. I do still have those concerns and I just don't know if this is, frankly, ever going to work.

Keeping kids safe online is one of the defining challenges of our time. My community wants to support the bill, but the extent to which it addresses challenges like bullying, screen addiction and access to harmful content like pornography is still unclear. For such a profound piece of legislation, the haste with which the government has rushed it through the parliament, the lack of engagement undertaken with affected stakeholders and the unanswered questions remain for many parliamentarians are alarming. Even if done right, an age limit for social media is a blunt instrument and certainly not a silver bullet. It may make some difference for parents—and I hope it does—but it is not the systems based approach that we need to make social media safe for all. I urge the government to delay the passing of the bill, undertake further consultation, do this better and, if need be, bring the parliament back early in the new year so we can probably consider this unprecedented piece of legislation. I want to keep kids safe from harm, but we need to do this in a responsible way, and rushing through legislation like this is not the way.

Mrs ARCHER (Bass) (20:54): I want to begin by stating that I certainly believe that social media has had a corrosive effect on our children and, indeed, on our society, but it's fair to say that the genie is well and truly out of the bottle and we are now having to find ways to restrain it, as stuffing it back in is not an option. The world has changed. The social media inquiry that has been referred to previously here today has demonstrated the immense harm that has been done to children by their interactions on these platforms, and there is no doubt in my mind that we need to take steps to address that. I've heard many devastating testimonies from parents, and I acknowledge and honour their lived experience.

I was supportive when the Leader of the Opposition stated that, if elected, we would take action on this issue in the first 100 days. And, to be clear, I unequivocally believe that we need to do something to give parents some tools to address the challenge. But I assumed that would happen by the normal processes—allowing both public and parliamentary scrutiny, building a social licence, taking the community on the journey with us. Instead, what we've got here is a politically expedient solution. What we're being asked to decide today is whether the approach before us is the solution. In and of itself I don't believe it is, or, at least, it isn't the whole solution. The wider point, though, is that the process has been so chaotic and so rushed that it's difficult to tell.

To start, I'll focus on some concerns about the bill itself that I have. I'm concerned about the undermining of parental responsibility, and I don't want parents to see this bill as a solution to the problems we've heard about, because I don't believe it is. There are all manner of dark places online and many more that can be used for nefarious purposes that aren't captured in the bill. Gaming and messaging platforms are not safe spaces either. Like other aspects of parenting, you will still need to make choices and decisions about what your children do or don't do online. I don't want parents to have a false hope that this is the answer.

I'm a parent of five children of varying ages, all of which have had various interactions in digital spaces. Like any parent I'm aware of the challenges the digital world presents in addition to some of the benefits. Like many parents, I utilise parental controls on devices to limit time and content, but this can be challenging, and I think more work can and should be done to educate and empower parents to use some of the tools that are already available. And, as a parent, I'd value more education and information to help navigate this space.

This continues to be a rapidly evolving space, and, as parents, part of the challenge is just keeping up with the changes and the pace of them. This has been exacerbated, as we've heard previously, by the pandemic provisions that meant more people were interacting with the online world in ways that they never had before and for extended periods of time.

I saw a comment from Patrick McGorry online yesterday, and I agree—we make swimming pools safe for kids by teaching them to swim, providing lifeguards and limiting poor or dangerous behaviour. We don't crudely ban access. Rather than simply banning kids from selective platforms, more must be done to make platforms create a safer environment for kids, for everyone.

I'm concerned that we've not had an opportunity to hear from young people themselves. I note that the minister said that part of the reason for the long implementation period is to allow for consultation with young people to occur. It's my view that that consultation should happen prior to the legislation being passed so it can be considered. I'm concerned that due consideration has not been given as to how to manage the transition for children already on these platforms, particularly those who may be vulnerable, such as neurodiverse and LGBTIQ+ cohorts, or geographically or otherwise isolated kids. What, if any, supports may be offered to manage this and not to create unintended mental health outcomes for these young people?

Again, I note that the minister talked of this bill having intersections with other portfolios and that there'll be policies to complement this bill across health, education, social services, mental health and the Attorney-General's department. What are these policies?

And, of course, I have some concerns for privacy. I commend the member for Banks for his work on this bill, particularly in relation to those privacy concerns, and those concessions that have been secured have strengthened the provisions, apparently meaning that no-one will be compelled to use digital ID or documents such as passports and that other choices must be offered. But I'm still concerned. On the one hand we're saying we don't trust the multitrillion dollar social media platforms to provide protections from harm for children, but we're being asked to take on trust that they will destroy personal information that they collect on the threat of a fine. Ultimately, my biggest objection to this bill is related to trust. We've seen a significant decline in trust in governments in recent years, and we've seen that play out recently with opposition to digital ID and the mis- and disinformation legislation. It's unfortunate that this bill follows so closely after the defeat of the misinformation bill. Despite all the protestation and assurances to the contrary that this bill is not a Trojan Horse of some kind, the fact remains that a significant number of people believe it is, and perception is important in establishing and maintaining trust.

That's where the rubber hits the road for me. The process that has led us to this point has been extremely inadequate. The social media inquiry that we've heard about, while extremely valuable and informative, was not in response to these draft laws but a forerunner to them. The inquiry responding to the tabling of this bill was hastily opened and closed for submissions in 24 hours. Submissions were curtailed in length, and no genuine consideration or regard to them could possibly be completed in the couple of hours of inquiry. The bill came in here on Thursday. Our party rooms only considered them this morning. Yet the outcome was seemingly a fait accompli, with arrangements already in place to curtail debate in here and ram it through. There are no government speakers at all, and I had to fight to even deliver this speech. I reject the notion of urgency in pushing this through now. It doesn't come into effect for over a year, and, by the government's own admission, there is a lot more work to do in that time.

The parliament matters, the work we do here matters, because trust matters. Processes like this don't do anything to build trust and confidence in institutions and governments. That matters. It matters because it directly compromises everything we might try to achieve with this bill and other bills. The less trust we have, the harder it will become to act in the future. I suspect there will be ongoing calls for further action in this space. The government has allowed itself to be goaded into acting with unseemly and unnecessary haste, and, because it has support, it's happy to make it up on the run. I can't help but note the contrast between their approach to this complex, multifaceted challenge and their complete unwillingness to deal with the much more straightforward proposition of banning gambling advertising, which demonstrably causes equal harm in our community, with the perverse outcome that kids under 16 will still be subjected to a saturation level bombardment with gambling ads—captured by vested interests but now hiding behind the smoke and mirrors of protecting kids online.

I've heard many times in here tonight that we can't let the perfect be the enemy of the good, but I feel that is a euphemism for, 'We know this is not that great, but it's the best we've got at the moment.' We don't even know if this approach is good yet, and the process has been wholly inadequate. It's easy to say, 'Just let it go through to the keeper because we think it's a noble objective,' but what about next time, when it's not? That is not what is expected of us as parliamentarians. I want to see work continue in this space. I want us to create safer spaces for all of us in this changed world. But, if it is worth doing, it is worth doing properly. That includes taking our community with us. My very strong preference would be for this bill to be deferred for proper scrutiny and consultation, as we've heard from other members here today. That would give an opportunity for that process to be corrected and to take more of our community along with us. But, disappointingly, it is clear that there is no appetite for that.

Because of that, I won't be supporting this bill under these circumstances. I reiterate that this is an important space, and it is something that we need to do something about. I will continue to engage constructively on this issue. I urge the government to give consideration to deferring this bill and give it further due scrutiny so that it can assuage some of the concerns that some of us have had and expressed in here and so that we can do more work in taking our community along on this important journey.

Ms BELL (Moncrieff) (21:04): It's good to stand to speak on the Online Safety Amendment (Social Media Minimum Age) Bill 2024. There are some in our community who are sceptical about this legislation. As a Liberal, I can understand why. There have been many emails in my inbox from constituents with concerns, and I really would like to address those concerns. I acknowledge those who sent emails about freedom of liberty, freedom of speech, overreach by the government and privacy or digital ID concerns, in particular. I very much respect their views on this bill, and so I want to address those first before talking about the whats, the whos and the hows of this particular bill.

Firstly, I want to share one submission to Labor's very short 24-hour inquiry by my local priest in Surfers Paradise, who is also a member of my Moncrieff Community Cabinet, which is filled with community leaders and faith leaders. I thought it important that I read out his public submission, which he also sent to my inbox. He said: 'I'm writing to express my profound opposition to the proposed Online Safety Amendment (Social Media Minimum Age) Bill 2024. This legislation, under the guise of protecting children, represents a troubling overreach of government authority, violates the sanctity of personal privacy and undermines the freedoms that underpin a healthy and just society. My concern is rooted in a belief that government should protect liberties, not restrict them unnecessarily, and that the moral responsibility for guiding the young should lie with families and communities, not the state. As a priest, I believe it is the responsibility of families and communities, not the state, to guide children in their use of technology, and our role as a society should be to support and equip individuals to live with wisdom and freedom, not to impose authoritarian measures under the guise of safety.'

So I want to reassure the priest and many others in the community that the coalition have listened to their concerns and we have been working with the shadow minister and with the government to amend the bill in the Senate to make some very important changes. I might just highlight too, for those who sent those messages to my office's inbox—and I do read those—that there are also, in fact, many more emails in the inbox that support this bill, and no-one supports the bill more than those parents who want to help protect their children from online harm do.

So the coalition has negotiated some changes. We've significantly strengthened the planned legislation in at least two areas of concern. Firstly, in relation to privacy, I want to outline that those privacy issues are really of utmost importance to us in the coalition and many of our supporters. That's why we've worked to strengthen this legislation, and this bill prohibits platforms from using information collected for age-assurance purposes for any other purpose unless explicitly agreed to by the individual. Once information has been used for age assurance, it must be destroyed unless the individual agrees to it being retained. Further to that, failure to delete information constitutes a breach of the Privacy Act. The Office of the Australian Information Commissioner will also provide oversight of the privacy provisions related to this bill. There will be new provisions stating that people cannot be compelled—I'll repeat that these are new provisions we have negotiated, stating that people cannot be compelled—to provide digital ID or government issued identity documents, such as drivers licences or passports, under this legislation.

Also, following our discussions with the government, changes will be made so that the Minister for Communications will be able to make rules specifying actions that social media platforms are not required to take in order to comply with the legislation. This will enable important ministerial oversight of the process by which the eSafety Commissioner issues guidelines under the new laws. That's very important. It's a bit of a safety net for the eSafety Commissioner, as the minister will have oversight. These are important changes which the coalition and the shadow minister believe will strengthen this bill.

Why do we need this bill to start with? Is this a seminal moment for our country? I'd like to talk about why Australian families need this bill and why Australian children aged under 16 need this bill. As lawmakers, we really must do what we can to keep our children safe, and, as the proud grandmother of an eight-year-old, a five-year-old, an 18-month-old, a two-week-old and another one coming in March, I couldn't sleep at night if I were to let an opportunity pass where I could do something to keep those children and everybody else's children safe from online harm. We must do what we can. We come to this parliament to protect our children, and that is our task. This bill absolutely seeks to achieve that. If we, as adults, don't do all we can to bring the online environment in line with the real world, then we're failing to keep our future generations safe from harm.

We know there's widespread concern and evidence about the severe mental health impact of social media on children, and we've seen disturbing global trends in youth mental health since the rise of social media, especially for girls. I want to outline some evidence. According to the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, there has been more than a threefold increase in the rate of intentional self-harm and hospitalisations for girls under 14 from 2008-09 to 2022-23. There have been large increases in the rate of mental health issues amongst children and young people. As at 2022, there was an independent report on self-harm commissioned by Australia's TGA that noted the very large increases in all intentional self-poisonings in older children, adolescents aged 10 to 19—this is very confronting—worldwide over the recent decade.
Finally, a clinical psychologist, Dr Danielle Einstein, told the Senate inquiry into the bill that any benefits of social media to mental health are far outweighed by the disadvantages. She said:

I do not see any benefits for mental health in social media. I've looked really hard at the evidence. Even if there were to be some, I think they are far outweighed by the disadvantages. For mental health, I do not see any benefits.

I believe, the coalition believes, my colleagues believe and the member for Forrest believes that this legislation will not only provide protections for our young but also, importantly, arm parents with the laws to give them some help to set guardrails for their children so they can say, 'No,' with confidence. They can say, 'No,' to harms, bullying, body shaming and eating disorders, inappropriate content, R-rated content, bullies and, especially, predators—those things have pushed young people to the brink, to take their own lives because of what they've been exposed to online. It must stop.

I will highlight who it was that led this debate. It was a man who has spent his entire adult life protecting women and children, particularly, from harm. The Leader of the Opposition, Peter Dutton, has led the national debate on this social media age limit, and in June the coalition committed to implementing an age limit of 16. Our leader announced that a coalition government would raise the age of social media access to 16 and said it would be at the top of his priority list for his first 100 days in office. Make no mistake, he has arm-wrestled the government to this position. It comes after the coalition led the policy debate about the need for action around online safety, including our attempts to legislate an age-verification scheme last November and the introduction of the world-leading online safety act in government. Five months after the Leader of the Opposition announced support for setting an age limit for social media, the Prime Minister has now jumped on board.

The bill is designed to set an age limit of 16 to reduce the harms that social media is causing to young people. The bill provides for a new broader definition of social media companies, which is age-restricted social media platforms will now capture Snapchat as well as other major social media platforms such as TikTok, Facebook, Reddit, Instagram and X. Importantly, there will be a rule-making power for the minister to exclude specific classes of services from the definition. In plain speak, that means there's a carve out for messaging services, online games—which many young people enjoy, including my grandchildren—and services that support the health and education of users, including YouTube, WhatsApp, Messenger Kids, ReachOut's PeerChat and Google Classroom. So this is not the end of the use of devices; this is simply a better option than doing nothing to keep our children safe online. It requires social media companies to take reasonable steps to prevent age-restricted users from having an account with a social media platform.

Penalties will apply. Failures to comply with the privacy provisions could result in fines of up to $50 million—that has got to hurt—and failures to take reasonable steps to identify underage users could result in fines of up to $49.5 million. We know children will get around it, and some parents will get around it with their children. That's the reality of laws and not complying with laws. People get around laws all the time. But it's better than the alternative because, for the overwhelming majority of parents who want to protect their children from online harm, this bill will help them to help their children, and that's so very important. As the party that believes in the strength of the family unit, this is a very important step for healthier families and for healthier young people suffering due to what they are being exposed to online. We must do this because it is the right thing to do, and the alternative—to do nothing—is simply not an option.
Ms LE (Fowler) (21:17): I'll start by using a quote from Aristotle's book, Aristotle Politics:
Man is by nature a social animal …

We humans are inherently social creatures who thrive in communities, according to Aristotle. We look for our tribes to belong to. We get pulled to groups and peoples. Aristotle explores the idea that individuals cannot achieve their full potential in isolation and that social interactions are essential for a well-functioning society. Today internet technology, mobile devices and social media platforms have brought our social interactions and connectivity to a level never seen before. It is now quicker and easier to access information and find people anywhere, anytime. It has shrunk the world and brought us all so close together virtually.

Who would have thought that I could see and speak with my relatives in Vietnam living in a province two hours drive from Saigon or Ho Chi Minh City? My aunt's life and that of my relatives have certainly benefited from the convenience of accessing information and seeing them via Facebook Messenger. I can see that their lives have been transformed, and it helps us stay connected. Technology has also helped online social capital development to connect people, share information, build relationships and promote cooperation between communities and businesses, whether my local business or learning of fundraising in another state or a social movement in other parts of the globe.

We have heard how social media is increasingly causing mental harm, especially among young people. It's addictive, even for adults. But is it the government's role to intervene in a family's life? Is legislating a ban for those under 16 from accessing social media the right move, even if it prevents bullying or harm to young people online? Like many members in this House would have experienced, my office has been inundated by emails as well as messages via social media platforms from parents and young children opposing the government's proposed ban on under-16s accessing social media.
I would like to read from a constituent who took the time to write a very detailed message to me. This is his message:

Unfortunately social media ban is like a blank cheque for the government. It will only push children to other platforms like discord which is not part of the ban. Unfortunately, I believe that the government is using this as a trojan horse to require verification of every Australian on social media and that's why it's targeting that. Bullying doesn't happen necessarily in the way you think, blocking, private restricted accounts etc actually are already in use, good example is Instagram. Bullying is happening via chat programs mostly discord.
Discord is a platform for young people to chat online, if people don't know that. He continues:

Schools have intervene when students or parents report the bullying, and it's dealt with that way, some reported to police. It gets dealt with. Bullying would not be stopped with the bill, it will just migrate somewhere else. The other aspect is the algorithm of social media giants that program your death scroll feed. Is this damaging yes, should there be transparency yes. But the ban does not solve that. You are only delaying the time before they are exposed to it. It's best to educate children on the problems of the death scrolling on their attention span, to recognise themselves when they find themselves doing it, but children aren't the only people impacted adults are as well. The positive side is children talk about what they are seeing, and have conversations about it, share their feelings and thoughts. I have a 15 and 12 year old boys. Both use social media differently. They were forced onto this platforms quite quickly in the pandemic. This is where the popularity of discord exploded. I use it, and my misses uses it for University. We connect study, game, chat, hold social gatherings, discuss topics, and even council each other. Pulling the plug could actually lead to harm, anyone that cannot freely express themselves, reach out to someone, could lead to isolation. We are then shifting the problem once more. The way to deal with bullying and the algorithm is transparency. A great example is TikTok, compare China's TikTok vs the rest of the Western world. One is like a children's classroom, and the other can be like a cesspool. Interesting thing I have noticed is overtime, children are rejecting and pushing back on what they are seeing. The gender ideology was very pervasive and after about 1.5 years it has slowly been overcome with a new more healthy culture where children have memed it out of existence, creation of cryptic terms that negate the need/importance of it and to no longer bring it even into focus anymore. Whilst it's still being pushed, it is retracting quite alot, I believe this is because also that adults are pushing back on the ideology and whether or not we should even provide it air time for children and like in many countries not entertaining any drastic decisions until they are mature adults.
He continues:

We need to evolve our programs rather devolve into a nanny state that creates dependants that cannot be socially responsible in society. Some hearts in government are in the right place, but unfortunately it's not going to improve our children's resilience nor prepare them for the future. Creating social culture using social media, celebrating excellence and bettering yourself, will drive the right behaviours. Children will put down their devices to study when they are encouraged to do better for themselves. Motivation is sometimes a problem, and escapism is occurring on social media, culture of helping and motivating others is what needs to be taught, and this is how we can transform the social media at the roots.
He continues:
Children do not watch the news anymore, they have absolutely no interest. They are only interested in culture now and really we should be focused on this and not a ban.

To John's point, we have become so reliant on our devices and by default on social media. We're now so dependent on it. Even my husband and my son are constantly scrolling on their phones at home. My husband has an online renewables business, so he has to make sure he's connected to his clients, and they're constantly checking their website and servicing their clients across the country. When they're not checking their business, they're either browsing the web, playing games or chatting to colleagues and friends. Sometimes I too feel very exasperated, because they're on their devices constantly, but we put a rule in place that, when we're together as a family, the phone is put aside. Another rule is that, when we go to bed, the phone is outside the bedroom. We've got no devices in our bedrooms, not even a TV. As a parent, I had a conversation with my son and my husband on how we manage our time on social media. I don't want the government to tell me how to run my household. Why would a parent trust the government to do better at managing their lives?

Last week I spoke on the government's intention to introduce the misinformation and disinformation bill, or the MAD bill, as the acronym represents. As we know, the government has now dropped the bill, with the Senate not willing to pass it. The intention of the MAD bill, or the misinformation and disinformation bill, was for the social media platforms to take responsibility for the content that gets posted and for these platforms to do all they can to ensure that they are responsible for the content that gets shared.

Trust is the foundation for any type of relationship. It's the fundamental component in forming relationships of any kind. We engage with social media content because we can trust the content. We listen to it. We watch it. But, once that trust is broken, we then move to find other, more trustworthy content.

I understand that we're all trying to grasp the growth of social media and all trying to find ways to navigate this new beast we all have come to depend on and, at times, despise. This bill has long been anticipated because the government has spoken about it so often in the media. It is therefore very disappointing, yet again, that the House of Representatives has been given just a few days over the weekend to scrutinise this bill. This gives none of us sufficient time to consult with stakeholders or our constituents, whose views we are obliged to canvass. It is our constituents who we ultimately represent, and I think that the government has forgotten that. If they ask their constituents, they may find out what I have. I have never had a single person approach me anywhere telling me that they want under-16s banned from social media. Never did I have anyone asking me for a misinformation bill. I have, however, been inundated in my electorate of Fowler, as I mentioned, by emails and phone calls from concerned residents about the misinformation bill, the Digital ID Bill and the anticipation of this online safety amendment bill.

As you can sense, I'm going to oppose this legislation, just like I did with the now doomed misinformation bill. My main reason for opposing these bills is that I firmly believe that they erode personal responsibility, undermine parents, restrict freedom of expression and may inadvertently do more harm than good. I would like to know what research has been done with regard to the effect that this bill will have on families. Replacing the fundamental discretion and responsibility of parents with laws must surely impact the functionality of Australian families. When it comes to individual responsibility, history tells us that, once government takes over what was up until then an individual choice, it is seldom reversed and never empowering.

I know that all members in this House are deeply and genuinely concerned about the scourge of bullying. I know that we've all been shocked and deeply moved by the reports of suicide and self-harm by children. But bullying between children is not a new phenomenon. In fact, cutting children off from social media may well remove a vital source of help for them. Many government and charitable organisations have a presence on these platforms that children can safely access. The social media platforms affected by this bill are places where young people benefit from positive interaction while gaming and sending messages, for example, as they learn how to operate in the world. We have also been approached by children and organisations as well as academics who have opposed this bill because they felt that they were not given sufficient time, and they know that social media provides children with a place for them to connect with their peers.

I think that this bill is misplaced in terms of interfering with the rights and responsibilities of parents and guardians. I think the bill seeks to avoid a problem by attacking a symptom. Can we not learn from the experiences of others? ChildFund Australia have told me that 10 other countries have trialled age related bans, and each one has failed. Under-16s have always found ways around the restrictions, and this has made children less safe because they often end up in darker and less exposed areas of the internet. These are places where predators and scammers are most dangerous. We have to remember that children are very creative and also resilient. Give them that credit.

I must admit to finding it very difficult to suspend my suspicions that the MAD bill, this online safety amendment bill and the digital ID legislation are not connected somehow, and I know that I'm not alone in this suspicion. I believe that parents and families are best to form and apply the rules. It may not be perfect, but it is better than the alternative. For this reason I will not be supporting the bill.

Mrs MARINO (Forrest) (21:30): I have some serious concerns with the government's process and the rushed nature of the Online Safety Amendment (Social Media Minimum Age) Bill 2024. But I want to talk about some of the dreadful harms that I know children have been, and are being, exposed to online through social media. I believe the online platforms could have and should have been doing much more over the years to help keep our children and young people safe online. I believe they've always had the capacity to do so but have chosen not to do so.

Early in my time as an MP, I was a member of the communications committee that did a report into cybersafety and young people. I realised from that survey just what they were dealing with online and how much risk they were exposed to. I developed a set of overheads and was encouraged by the Harvey business and professional women's group to offer it to our local primary school—and that was the start. I have delivered hundreds of cybersafety sessions to schoolchildren, from pre-primary through to high school. In this time, in all these 14-or-so years, I have seen a serious decline in the mental health and wellbeing of our young people. Along the way I provided parent sessions for those parents who were interested. This was all aimed at helping children to stay safe online and to know where to go to get help, mostly through encouraging families to get involved from the day the first device is given to their child.

A number of schools in my electorate have asked me to come in each year or when there was a particular problem in their schools caused by online behaviour or the constantly evolving risks with certain games, apps and sites. I want to thank the schools and the parents who have come along to these sessions. Over the years a number of teachers have quietly said, 'You have saved lives today.' Principals and teachers will welcome the age restriction. In one instance, one of the principals I was dealing with, who had massive problems in his school, asked me to give him an enlarged copy of the age verification—the age that children are meant to be on some of the social media sites, games and apps. He held it up at a school assembly and said to the parents: 'If your children have any issues in relation to any of this, this is the age they're meant to be online. This is something for you to deal with. If they are online, they're not old enough to be online, using those games, apps, sites and social media. It is up to you to deal with it.' I hope that this legislation may help parents say no.

When you look at the top-five social media services being used—this is from the eSafety Commissioner some time ago—for YouTube it's 80 per cent of kids and 86 per cent of teens; for Facebook it's 26 per cent of kids and 75 per cent of teens; for Snapchat it's 26 per cent of kids and 67 per cent of teens; and for Instagram it's 24 per cent of kids and 70 per cent of teens.

When I've been talking to the parent and the children, there are some things this legislation will certainly deal with. One is Instagram. For some people who aren't aware, the GPS coordinates are embedded in the photos. This is and has been something that is unsuitable for anyone under the age of 13. Snapchat, that photo-sharing app, which was only supposed to leave your photos there for a few seconds and then they would disappear—well, I had so many young people in my electorate who actually thought that they could send naked and semi-naked photos and no-one would know. This, of course, became the sexting app of choice, and there was a snap map that then allowed others to see that young person's location. It was called Snap Map, and it allowed people on Snapchat to follow these kids.

I would say to kids and parents, the only person who should be tracking and mapping your children is you as a parent, if you choose to do that. No-one else should be tracking or mapping your children, but that is happening on so many games, social media and other apps. I encourage parents to make sure that you are aware of which of these can actually track and map your children. It is the same with TikTok—in the way that young people are using TikTok. It was intended for users over 16, but it didn't ask for an age at all. Young people, definitely, were sharing very provocative information.

These are some of the experiences that countless young people have raised with me over the past years: relentless, appalling cyberbullying, 24 hours a day, seven days a week—you cannot get away from it; abusive texts and emails; hurtful messages, images or videos; imitating others online; excluding others online; humiliating others and nasty gossip on social media platforms; unwanted contact; and online grooming of adults wanting sex from a child. There are literally adults grooming children for sex in this space. There is no doubt it is a paedophile's paradise. There is a constant pressure for young people to send naked photos followed up by sextortion and image based abuse. And you wonder why we've seen so much self-harm and attempted suicide in young people.
